conclusion: Understanding shadow formation involves opaque objects blocking light, affecting shadow shape and position.
Shadow direction is away from the light source, defined by lines from the light source past object edges.
If the light source moves right, shadows move left on the ground.
Shadows A, B, and C shift left when the light source moves right.
Shadow size and shape depend on object shape, light source distance, and angle of light rays.
Shadow A moves left, appears longer and potentially narrower.
Shadow B shifts left with relatively similar size and shape.
Shadow C shifts left, changes shape and size, becoming more compact.
Summary: Shadows A, B, and C move left; A becomes longer, B changes less, C becomes more compact.
